title: What are the equations of tangents to the circle x² + y² = 10 from the point (-2,4)? - Quora

response.answer_text: Equation of the circle is x^2+ y^2 = 10. or,(x-0)^2+(y-0)^2=(√10)^2.,thus the centre of the circle is (0,0) and radius=√10.units. (1) y - 3x -10 = 0. Thus , the equations of two tangents are 3y+x-10=0 and y-3x-10=0. Answer.

What are the equations of tangents to the circle x² + y² = 10 from the point (-2,4)? Solution: There can be only one tangent at any point on the circle. The centre of the circle is O (0,0). Point A (-2,4) lies on the circumference of the circle. The equation of the line OA is (x-0)/(-2–0) = (y-0)/(4–0), or -x/2 = y/4, or 2y = -4x, or y = -2x. The tangent to the circle at A will be perpendicular to OA. So its slope will be (1/2). So the equation of the tangent: y = (1/2)x + c, or 4 = (1/2)*(-2) + c, or c = 4+1 = 5 So the equation of the tangent is y = (x/2) + 5, or 2y = x+10. Answer.
